Award.AwardTitle: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: How do seedlings survive? Hydraulics, carbon acquisition and drought tolerance in the earliest phases of tree growth
Award.AbstractNarration: Tree species distributions can shrink over time through reduced regeneration and subsequent adult mortality or they can expand via seedling establishment beyond current distribution boundaries. Therefore, a critical component of our ability to predict future species distributions is an understanding of the mechanisms of seedling establishment, which requires a fundamental knowledge of seedling physiology. The water pathway from the root to the leaf is critically important for maintaining leaf water status and allowing stomata to stay open, resulting in carbon capture through photosynthesis. However, water transport in the plant is vulnerable to desiccation-induced changes, including vascular tissue embolism (i.e. air bubble formation). The overall objective of this research is to understand the mechanisms responsible for prevention of hydraulic failure (i.e. catastrophic embolism) in tree seedlings, thereby ensuring adequate photosynthesis for their survival and establishment. Survival, growth, physiology and anatomy of growing seedlings will be measured to assess desiccation tolerance and the impacts of drying on photosynthesis, and to determine when structures that regulate seedling water loss develop. Results from this research can be directly used in modeled predictions of vegetation responses to climate change because seedling survival is likely a primary determinant of species distributions. These findings will also be of interest to policy makers and land managers who are interested in potential drought impacts on productivity and distributions of certain species. They will also be of interest to tree and woody crop breeders concerned with identifying traits associated with survival and adequate productivity in given environments. In addition, the ideas and methodology of measuring young seedling hydraulic parameters will be of interest to the plant science community and could provide a springboard for a new area of research activity. The project includes training of two graduate students, several undergraduate students and high school students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There were two major activities undertaken in this project. First, we focused on differences in the ability of tree seedlings in their first year of growth (germinants) from two populations each of two conifer species to tolerate drought and heat stress. The populations differed in the climate where their parental trees had been growing, with one population of each species coming from a hotter and drier habitat than the other population. Second, we conducted a series of experiments on species that differed in the stringency with which they maintain their leaf hydration, as assessed by leaf water potential measurements. Some plant species (dubbed more “isohydric”) maintain their leaf water potential at mild levels by closing the stomata (pores through which carbon dioxide is absorbed by leaves but also through which water evaporates) on their leaves under conditions of water stress. At the other end of this continuum of stringency are more “anisohydric” species that keep their stomata open during water stress, which causes their leaf water potentials to reach more extreme values. There has been much interest in the physiological differences among species that lie along this continuum because the different strategies may have implications for species’ ability to survive drought stress.

For each of the two major activities listed above we conducted specific projects. Below, we have listed specific objectives for each activity as well as a brief description of how that objective was carried out and results from the experiments.

1. Determine if germinants of ponderosa pine from populations that differ in climate vary in their ability to tolerate drought stress. To test this we conducted a common garden experiment on germinants from two populations of ponderosa from contrasting environments. We examined a variety of physiological and anatomical traits. Ponderosa pine germinants from the drier, hotter environment exhibited a much more conservative suite of traits, including gaining more carbon dioxide per water lost, smaller biomass, and earlier budset in the fall.  

2. Assess thermotolerance in germinants of ponderosa pine and Douglas-fir from populations that differ in climate. This experiment was conducted in a greenhouse and parameters such as the health of the light absorption machinery, the integrity of the cell membranes, gas exchange of carbon dioxide into and water out of the leaves, and components of the non-structural carbohydrate pool were measured. Species-level differences were observed in the metrics of thermotolerance. For example, detached needles of Douglas-fir germinants had healthier photosynthetic machinery and had better cell membrane integrity under heat stress than in ponderosa. Whole germinants exposed to heat treatments exhibited an increase in glucose + fructose concurrent with a decrease in starch in both species, whereas total non-structural carbohydrates and sucrose were not affected by heat treatment. Populations did differ in their water-use efficiency, the amount of carbon gained per water lost, but not thermotolerance, which appeared to be more easily adjusted by the plant. 

3. Develop metrics and/or proxies that can be used to assess the degree of stringency with which stomata regulate leaf water potential (ie, the degree of iso- vs. anisohydry). For this project we grew saplings of ten species that differed in their wood density (which correlates with degree of anisohydry) and the degree of aridity in their habitat of origin. In the controlled setting of a greenhouse, we dried these plants down and monitored predawn and midday leaf water potential, when this parameter should be at its most and least favorable, respectively. From these experiments we investigated the usefulness of various metrics and proxies for each species’ degree of anisohydry, some of which are much easier to measure than traditional metrics to assess this trait. The proxies we developed should permit rapid assessment of many species. We have also extended this study by examining a variety of physiological and anatomical traits associated with the degree of anisohydry.

We have also broadened the impact of our research through a variety of activities. During the summer of 2013, we recruited a Hispanic intern through a joint program between the US Forest Service and the Hispanic Association of Colleges and Universities. HACU is an organization committed to Hispanic success in education, from kindergarten through graduate school and into the work force. A number of papers have been written based on the results from this project. We have published these in top-tier journals such as Tree Physiology, Plant, Cell and Environment, and Ecology Letters. We have also presented results at various conferences including annual meetings of the Ecological Society of America, the 2016 Gordon Conference on "Multiscale Plant Vascular Biology", and the 2015 workshop on "Emerging Frontiers in Plant Hydraulics."
